Title.evidence: Title: Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Incidence of Catheter-Related Bloodstream Infections in Central Venous Access Devices

Trial_Design.evidence: Randomisation methods varied, with some studies using appropriate randomisation and allocation concealment.

Intervention.evidence: Paired meta-analyses showed a lower incidence of CRBSIs in the peripherally inserted central catheter (PICC) group compared to the central venous catheter (CVC) group and the totally implantable venous access port (TIVAP) group.

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to compare the incidence of catheter-related bloodstream infections (CRBSIs) among different central venous access devices (CVADs).

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the incidence of CRBSIs, measured over the study duration.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation methods varied, with some studies using appropriate randomisation and allocation concealment.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was not feasible due to the nature of the intervention.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Five RCTs were included, with a total of 962 participants.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Paired meta-analyses showed a lower incidence of CRBSIs in the peripherally inserted central catheter (PICC) group compared to the central venous catheter (CVC) group (RR = 0.23, 95% CI 0.13–0.43, p < 0.00001) and the totally implantable venous access port (TIVAP) group (RR = 0.45, 95% CI 0.23–0.87, p = 0.02).

Trial_Registration.evidence: Trial registration and funding details were not provided.

Funding.evidence: Trial registration and funding details were not provided.
